statement:
There exists a Hadamard matrix of order $n$ = $4m$, for all
$m \in \mathbb{Z}^+.$

A Hadamard matrix of order 428 (m=107) has been recently constructed
[@KT].

.

A Hadamard matrix of order 764 has also recently been constructed
[@DZD].

Also, Paley’s theorem guarantees that there always exists a Hadamard
matrix $H_n$ when $n$ is divisible by 4 and of the form $ 2^e(p^m+1) $,
for some positive integers e and m, and p an odd prime and the matrices
can be found using Paley construction.

This leaves the order of the lowest unknown Hadamard matrix as 668.
There are 13 integers $m$ less than 500 for which no Hadamard matrix of
order $4m$ is known:
$$167, 179, 223, 251, 283, 311, 347, 359, 419, 443, 479, 487, 491$$ and
all of them are primes congruent to 3 mod 4.
